values:
Good things:
- Made it through the day
- Centers were pretty great, all things considered
- Running after work
- Haircut!  Thank god.  Trying a new stylist paid off.
- John made dal for dinner

Things I will bitch and moan about right now and then hopefully get over them:
- The blonde bitch who works across the hall being a bitch
- Stupid internet laws
- Being tired
- Grad school
- Doing dishes by hand

That is all.

Going to tell Ana "no" for sure tomorrow. Here's (roughly, and in a more eloquent form) what I'm planning to say. "I've thought a lot about what we talked about last week, and it's honestly something that's been on my mind for over a month now. I thought particularly about what you said about not basing my decision on a quarter's worth of planning-based stress, and I want to assure you that I have considered my whole experience at Rowe when thinking about what I want to do next year. "I'm going to be forthright and tell you that my experience here has been a hard one. It's taken a lot out of me to develop the way you've noticed me developing as a teacher and as a professional person, and I'm really not sure I can sustain this kind of work. Your advice about becoming a professional in a career has been valuable and thought-provoking for me, and it's led me to think about what I can sustain as a career. "Because I love teaching so much--I love seeing kids grow, I love seeing the light bulbs go off in their heads, and I love talking to kids about what they've learned--I am definitely going to be looking for opportunities within education for the future, something I know you know far more about than I do. I remember you saying that you helped Brian think about possibilities for his future, and Katie Kleczek was certainly grateful to you for the help you gave her this past summer. I'm hoping that, in my search for a new challenge, I can bounce ideas off of you and have you there as that cheerleader figure you have said you want to be. I am certainly planning on being a cheerleader for the academics at Rowe and working hard to ensure that they're the best they can be. So I hope I can count on your support throughout the next several months." AHHH.

Teehee.  I like "The Call."  Oh, those Backstreet Boys.

Anydangways.  I'm trying to journal more and record my thoughts on teaching and Rowe more consistently, rather than when I'm just feeling discouraged or elated.  John suggested that, in order to help me make a decision about where I'll work next year, I keep a running list of pros and cons about Rowe.  Or just make more consistent writings about my feelings about the place.

So, let's see.  This week has been odd.  Monday we started new groups after our SEL instruction at 12:40, and I'm doing explicit sight word instruction.  That has been improving over the course of the week; the first day, I stood up there teaching for too long and didn't execute the lesson the way it was supposed to be executed.  However, I think that my kids are getting the hang of it--today, Edgar (who can't really talk at all) read the sentence "The dog is big."  The only clue he had was a picture of a dog under the word "dog," since he can't read that word yet.  Then Mason read "I am a big bird" and I was SO EXCITED.  They are starting to read!!!

That is one of the biggest pros of my job: the staff is capable and I am working with Anjali, an incredibly talented teacher who makes magical things happen in her scholars' brains.  I am merely riding the wave of that magic, I think, and I want to learn how to create it myself.  I'm growing as a professional and as a teacher, but I want to reach better heights.

All that being said, there are some serious things that irk me about my school.  One of those things is the leadership team.  Three out of five of them are being jackasses this year and just don't do what they need to do to contribute to the overall well-being of our school.  It's sometimes infuriating.  The decisions they make often have no basis in reality or they expect us to perform trivial tasks like it's the most important thing in our days.  I'm sorry, but no.  There are 25 children in my classroom and THEY are the most important things in my day.

However, I also feel SUCH a sense of accomplishment when I see my kids writing down letters because they now know the alphabet, to see the difference in their Summer Orientation data and their data not three months later, and to hear them READING FULL SENTENCES!!!!  It's amazing.  Another fantastic thing is seeing how much the smile when there is something interactive to do during one of our lessons.  I love kindergarten and kind of want to teach this grade forever.  Hopefully Ana will be able to find me a spot in K next year, if I stay.

One thing that scares me, though, is the workload and the pressure to achieve certain data benchmarks.  I don't doubt that I can do it; what makes me nervous is the amount of time and energy I know I will have to devote to my job if I accept a classroom lead teacher position for next year--which I know Ana is eager to give me.  There are moments like today, when I see the hard work I've put in paying off in scholars' learning.  However, there are also selfish moments (like that post I wrote last week) when I wish I had an 8-5 job in a clean environment and in which I didn't have to put in lots of extra work outside of the office.  Part of me knows I'd be bored stiff by that kind of work, though, so I end up in this awkward place where I don't really know where I'll be next year.

Anyway, one odd thing about this week was that yesterday, two out of three of the third/fourth grade teachers (they are departmentalized, so the classes switch for different subjects) were absent.  That meant that the administration hired ONE sub and then pulled THREE different co-teachers from their classrooms for a third of the day to teach third/fourth grade.  It was super-stressful.  While I don't mind pitching in for people when they're sick (lord knows people did that for me when I missed a whole week last year with the Peruvian death flu), I DO mind our administration not having a sound, sustainable process for securing adequate coverage for absent teachers without taking learning opportunities from the kids in the classes from which they pull teachers.  GRRRR.

Sigh.  I always end up with highly mixed feelings when I think about my job.  It's hard to know what to do . . .

I have been thinking on my career path, my past passions, and how they sort of fizzled out a lot lately. It's gotten me wondering if I want to stay in teaching, particularly given how relaxed I feel now that school is out and how much the thought of going back in the fall stresses me out. We'll see. More reflection later.

AHHHHH summer school teaching is over.






What.

Today my chilluns take their end-of-unit tests for CPS.  I'm getting pretty nervous for them.

Tomorrow, 5 of my students will take the ISAT to determine whether or not they can pass 6th grade.

Tomorrow and Thursday my students will take their math post-assessments for us.

Every day this week we'll be testing their individual reading skills, too.




We're all going to be so burned out on testing by Thursday.

I hope they pass.

Definitely listening to "I Gotta Feeling" by the Black Eyed Peas after talking to two of my 7th grade girls from Breakthrough last year--they're now 8th graders and, as I predicted, are pretty jaded on Breakthrough (it's just a thing that happens after kids have been through a year of middle school).  It's hard to convince them that things will be okay from like 3000 miles away, especially when I'm obviously absent and don't know exactly what's going on.  At least they said they miss me?  I certainly miss them, Breakthrough and its culture, and Santa Fe.  A lot.  Like, some days it's overwhelming how much I wish I was in the mountains at the IHM, doing cheers and writing songs.

At the same time, I'm becoming increasingly attached to my students from this summer.  I don't think I'll ever forget Jasean bugging me every day for his leadership tickets, Cornelius's look of surprise when I praised him for doing a great job in math, Delisa's desire to measure angles with a protractor correctly, the utter transformation that I've seen in Zhane's behavior since Day 1, and Hakeem's desire to show me his 7th grade-level work.  I could go on and on, but I really need to get back to planning my lessons for next week.

So the point is . . . even on nights like tonight when I'm sick and writing another lesson plan seems like it might ACTUALLY kill me, I remember Melissa and her laugh, Ivanna and her quiet sass, and my students from every summer I've taught . . . and it's all okay.

SAPPY I KNOW BUT YOU ARE JUST GOING TO HAVE TO DEAL WITH IT!!!

Tonight is the eve of week 3 of Institute. That means it's the second week of teaching. Even though it's only a three day week (due to the holiday tomorrow and us not having school on Fridays), I am not feeling less pressure to improve my teaching. If anything, fewer days means fewer tries to get it right. So I'm trying to get my mental focus back on my students. Last week was really difficult. I wouldn't say it was the most difficult week of my life, as many TFA people have expressed. It was certainly one of my more sleep-deprived weeks, but it wasn't the hardest. I was frustrated, excited, disappointed, flat-out angry, happy, and exhausted last week. It was a whirlwind that left me spinning, but with the solid conclusion that I really need to step up my time-management and execution. And that's what I am trying to focus on this week. Tomorrow is supposed to be a holiday, but we purportedly have a whole day of "sessions"--blocks of time led by veteran teachers who did TFA at the beginning of their teaching careers. Sessions are supposed to teach us the skills we need to be effective teachers in all facets of the job, but really what they are for me is a giant frustration. I want concrete strategies that help me deal with the issues I know I have. I completely acknowledge that TFA is trying to simultaneously equip us with the skills we'll need to do well this summer in addition to skills we'll need back in our regions (for me, Chicago), but it's really hard to know exactly what behavior management thing I need to focus on as a next logical step and then spend 3 hours in some session about lesson planning. Bleh. That's not to say that I don't have a deep respect and admiration for the veteran teachers who lead those sessions. They have a wealth of knowledge that they clearly found through years of hard work. I would just like to have more personalized interactions with them. And it's really a possibility--all I have to do is email or call them. In the coming weeks, I'm going to make a concerted effort to reach out to them when I need individual advice instead of just whining about how sessions are a waste of time or whatever. Indeed. Oh well. Looking on the brighter side of things, I'm determined to get 7 hours of sleep every night this week. I worked a lot this weekend to help put my planning ahead by a few days, and I'm really hoping it will help. Anyway. It's shower time, then a little lesson-planning, then bed.

Holy crap, it's been a month since I wrote in here?  Really?  Huh.

Oh well.  My excuse is that life has been busy.  Yesterday I was in scheduled TFA things from 7:25 - 4:15, then from 6:30 - 8.  It was exhausting, and today we get to do it all over again!  I am excited to start learning more concrete teaching strategies and such, and I think we're about to get into all of that this week.  So yay! for that.

But right now I am still very tired and in need of breakfast . . . so I will go downstairs in search of food and coffee.

- TFA Institute prep assignments!!
- Run a lot--hopefully most days
- Go through stuff, clean out old unwanted things and give to Goodwill/throw away
- Scavenge at Goodwill for potential useful things
- Eat well
- Toss a frisbee often
- Buy teacher clothes!!!



Ahgghghghgh.  I'm getting stressed out, even though my 2-ish week "vacation" has just started.  Blargle!

Well, it's graduation-eve.  I'm laying in bed in my hot, sticky, half-packed room and listening to Dar Williams's "Iowa" on repeat.  I'm overwhelmed by emotion and confusion about that emotion.  It's weird to think that tomorrow I will be really, truly done with Grinnell.  I know I've been whining about wanting this day to come for a while, and in many ways I am glad that tomorrow is commencement.  But the end of this year has been really strangely emotional in ways that I never expected.  I'm having a lot of trouble articulating what I'm feeling about leaving, but I'm sure of two things: (1) I am going to have a difficult time sleeping tonight and (2) I hope they have coffee at the English department breakfast tomorrow morning.

The end.

I am done with college.

Done.

Done.

DONE.

Forever.

Wow. 

That's kind of weird.

This weekend is going to be so surreal.

Oh my god.

But I am starting to look at it more positively.  Which is good.

It's so close to the end.  

I'm getting sad.  

And when I get sad about leaving Grinnell, you know something big is about to happen.

Yes.  It is time for a shower.  I smell gross.

Today I am starting my ENG 332 paper. I got an extension till Friday at noon, which is wonderful because I'm currently feeling rather overwhelmed--emotionally, physically, etc. But especially emotionally. 9:43pm: Working on an outline and learning a lot about the family in Victorian England. The outline is like 1.5 pages right now. Bleh. Listening to the PotC: CotBP soundtrack to keep my focus. 10:02pm: Casino Royale soundtrack now. Having a hard time caring about family values in Victorian England. Instead have just spent last 15 minutes or so on facebook, stalking my frisbee teammates. 10:25pm: Well there is just no way I am going to get anywhere on this paper tonight. I should really just cut myself off from the internet. But no. That would be bad. I don't know. Still listening to the Casino Royale soundtrack. 10:45pm: Am quickly figuring out which sources from my annotated bibliography will actually be useful for my paper. Also just received an email from one of my advisees from last summer. Also also got a facebook message from a BCN friend saying she will be in Chicago next year too! Hurrah. Positive positive positive. 11:03pm: Just went downstairs to get water. Am still terribly afraid of being murdered when alone in house sometimes. Tired. Want to go to bed. Will inevitably spend next two days writing this accursed paper. Then will collapse and try to relax over the weekend. Wednesday, May 19 2010, 11:29am: Back to work after a weird night's sleep. I had a bizarre dream in which my mom and David and I were in a store that sold earrings made of pretty stones, and that my mom was thinking about buying some for herself (this is only weird because she doesn't actually have her ears pierced). Then while I was wandering around the store, some of those ladies from Granada who were holding small sprigs of plants and offering to tell me my fortune started swarming around me in the store and I had to push them away every time they got close. It was bizarre. Anyway. Now I'm just procrastinating. Gah. LotR:TTT soundtrack today. 12:10pm: Just ate some delicious hash browns that I made while my coffee was getting ready. Mmmmm. My "outline" has devolved into 3 solid pages of quotes that I might find useful at some point or another. You would really think I would have this whole paper-writing thing better figured out by now, but no. I do not. 12:47pm: Oh dear. Yesterday in fit of procrastination registered on a realty website (don't worry, John, it is reputable--TFA recommends it--also it is free), and just now received call from friendly woman asking me all sorts of questions about where I want to live and when I want to move in and do I want parking. It was all very awkward and she was going to transfer me to a guy who "knows Bucktown really well" but then I was like, "Ummmm, I'm actually working on my last paper ever of undergrad, would it be okay if I just gave him a call some other time?" And now I feel weird about growing up and moving on. Is too weird to be dealing with realty agents and such. I am not ready. I mean, I ate 3 packages of fruit snacks and a plateful of hash browns for breakfast/lunch today. I am clearly not on the cusp of adulthood. AHHHHH. 1:41pm: Just spent a little while talking to Thomas. As much as I complain about my roommates, I will miss them when we're all dispersed all over the place. Also, my friend Leigh wrote a beautiful blog post recently about leaving places. I'm so glad she will be in Chicago next year. 2:23pm: Fuck. Haven't really done anything in the last 40 minutes. Crap crap crap. 3:14pm: Outline is 4 pages. I am getting antsy to start writing . . . This always happens: I get most of the way through an outline, say "screw it" then end up lost when I don't have anything else planned to say because I didn't finish my outline. I WILL FINISH MY OUTLINE. DAMNIT. 5:20pm: Super-not excited about this paper. Bleh. Am almost done with the historical/biographical research, though. Thank goodness. 8:09pm: 521/4000 words. That is to say, approximately 13% done. 8:27pm:713/4000 words. ~18% done. 8:51pm: 963 words. 24%. 9:40pm: After a brief bubbleshooter and HIMYM break, I am at 1167 words. That is 29%. Cool. 10:10pm: 1619 words. How is this possible? It does not feel like I have written that much. 40%?!?! 11:11pm: Make a wish. I have a headache and a jawache and just a couple hundred more words than I did at last update because I took a break from writing as a result of being so surprised with my impressive 1619 words. To celebrate I watched an episode of HIMYM and made some mozzarella sticks. Yum. Now back to work. Music: Scheherazade. Thursday, May 20 2010, 12:17am: Have transitioned to old band music unexpectedly. Now hearing the sweet stylins of MHS Wind Ensemble 2006 playing Blue Shades. Oh god. WHat is wrong with me. Too much caffeine and not enough sleep lately. Aaaaaaagggghhhh. 2080 words. 52% done. 12:36am: I think it is time for a shower then bed. 2522 words. 63%. 12:40pm: Tired tired tired. But it's time to start this madness again, and hopefully for the last time. The final countdown, as it were. Har har. Oh god. Too much coffee, not enough sleep. 1:17pm: 2696 words. 67%. 3:15pm: 3199 words. 80%. 3:47pm: 3409 words. 85%. 4:16pm: Just got back from the JRC where I made $95: $40 for selling old, unwanted books (farewell, Classics of Philosophy! Adeu, Ulysses!) and $55 for my bed and nightstand. Sweet. Now, back to the paper . . . 4:47pm: 3655 words. 91%. 5:08pm: 3873 words. 97%. 5:43pm: 4255 words. 106%. 7:29pm: 4764 words. 120%. 7:52pm: DONE WITH A DRAFT. 5232 words. 131%. 9:35pm: In the library, having done some edits realized needed at least one more paragraph to fully flesh out the argument of this paper. Bah! Oh well. Have applied edits and only need to finish this paragraph before will be done forever!!! 9:50pm: Done. Wow. It does not even feel real yet. 5536 words. That's 138% of the word count, bitches.

I'm finished with 2/3 classes.  My room is getting cleaner as I prepare to write the last paper.  I have coffee and it is sunny out.

None of this really matters very much, though.  Last night we found out that the student who was injured at a track meet this past weekend passed away.  I didn't know him well, but I knew him and had had some very positive interactions with him through frisbee--enough to know he was a friendly, kind person and that he meant a lot to the people around him.

I don't know what else to say other than that he will be missed.  Grinnell is going through some hard times.  Here's hoping things get better--although, really, it's going to take some time for the campus to heal from all the hurting that's been going on the last few weeks.

I'm feeling crappy about being in Grinnell right now. I wonder why? Maybe it's because . . . - Last night someone decided it would be a good idea to write some violently anti-queer things in the dorms--one comment was written on a poster, another was carved into a fucking door. I'm so tired of this school being filled up with hate and I'm so tired of seeing people I care about feel threatened because they chose to attend this institution of higher education or whatever it is. - I have terrible cramps. - I actually cannot decide what to do about nationals, and as a result I'm feeling crappier than ever about a friendship that I once considered my best at this school. - I have to write a philosophy paper. - A guy from the men's frisbee team who is also on track got seriously injured at a meet in IL this weekend. He is apparently in critical condition. Clearly only the first, third, and last ones are really wearing on me emotionally. I mean, yeah the philosophy paper sucks, but whatever. I can handle it. What I can't handle is being in this environment, living with a roommate with whom I am currently what I can only describe as "furious." It's also really difficult to know someone and then hear that they are in the hospital--not that I know him very well personally, but we knew each other from frisbee . . . and it just sucks to hear that a good person got hurt. I've thought about going to nationals as a way to escape said "friend" and the terrible, terrible environment that some assholes have decided is their right to create on this campus. Part of me thinks that that's not a constructive way of dealing with either of the situations. Part of me really wants to stay here for commencement weekend to see the people who have been good to me and to make sure we can make some good memories before we all disperse all over the world. Part of me wants to punch a certain someone in the face, but I will refrain in favor of a serious conversation about how I've felt bad about myself all year because he decided to ditch all of his former friends in favor of some new people just because they happen to live with his girlfriend. I'm tired of feeling abandoned, uncomfortable, and like I can't confide in anyone here. I'm tired of it. I'm so fucking tired of this place that I really do want to go to nationals in a way. I don't know what to do. NATIONALS PRO AND CON LIST PROS: - Get to play frisbee - Get to hang out with frisbee friends - Don't have to worry about the awkwardness of hanging around in Grinnell and meeting people's families and trying to avoid a certain someone - Don't have to explain awkwardly to captain-friend that I am not going to nationals as promised and why - Don't have to be around the friends of friends I don't really care for at all; also, don't have to be around that one "friend" CONS: - Miss seeing people who have been important to me for 4 years - Miss out on some "important" ceremonies or whatever - Don't get back until late Sunday night - Don't get to see alum friends who are coming back for the weekend very much at all - Have to leave Block Party early - Don't get to relax and try to enjoy the very end of my time in Grinnell - Less time to pack and organize all my shit From the looks of those lists in terms of numbers alone, it seems like I am more inclined to stay. However, I really don't want to feel like I'm letting the team down . . . although I haven't been to practice/anything they've done as a team in like 2 weeks. So I don't know. Also I don't always feel super-included by them. Also I will just be uncomfortable anywhere I go, so what does it matter in the end. BUH--WAIT FOR IT--ARF.

So, basically I am procrastinating hardcore on my philosophy paper outline, but I decided to make a list of the books I've read in 2010. Mostly they were for class, but that's okay. I liked the ones I finished. - Dracula - Frankenstein - The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde - In Memoriam - The Mill on the Floss - The Castle of Otranto - A Christmas Carol - The Turn of the Screw - Adventures of Huckleberry Finn - Walden - The Princess Diaries, vols 1, 2, and 3 - Bridget Jones's Diary - Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason Possibly there are others. But I can't think of them right now. Here are some awards I would like to give to these books: The Most Terrifying Book Award goes to . . . The Turn of the Screw! The Best New Book I've Read All Year Award goes to . . . Adventures of Huckleberry Finn! The Most Tedious Thing I've Read All Year Award goes to . . . In Memoriam! The Weirdest Book I've Read All Year goes to . . . The Castle of Otranto! Perhaps I will think of more awards once I've read more books. But perhaps not.

Today I have felt:

- Tired
- Nauseous
- Sad
- Angry
- Apathetic
- Proud

Today I have done the following things instead of reading in preparation for my philosophy paper:
- Napped
- Played bubble shooter
- Made a sandwich

The following are all that stand between me and being completely done with the academic part of my last year of college:
- 1 English class
- 1 Philosophy paper
- 1 English paper

This morning I woke up to a weird sound.  It was kind of like a clicking noise and for some reason I thought the magnetic plug for my computer was detaching and then re-attaching itself to Logan Jr.  But when I got up to inspect, the sound was coming from the area near my bookshelf.  Perplexed, I went back to bed but couldn't fall asleep again because of the continual noise.

Eventually I figured out by looking at the area near my bookshelf that it was, in fact, water dripping onto a big pile of plastic shopping bags that I've been keeping for no real reason.  So, great, my ceiling was leaking (did I mention it was storming when I woke up?  Because it was).  At first I was a little bit upset about it, but at some point while I was getting dressed I just decided not to be upset by it.  That expression about not crying over spilled milk came to mind.  Whatever.  It's just another reason to be all the more excited about getting a new apartment in a new city and starting a new job with new people.  And I mean, yeah I still have some weird social anxiety about starting all over, but I do know several people who are going to be in Chicago next year, and I'll have John and all.  So I'm not too worried anymore.  I'm mostly just excited to get out of Grinnell.

So, I'm importing pictures into iPhoto for the first time . . . and as the program flashes all of the pictures I'm adding, I get weird little snapshots of my time at Grinnell. Suffice it to say that I'm not really sad about it being almost over. EDIT (11:35pm): Another thing about which I am not sad: being almost done with this bullshit American lit class. My throat is very sore and dry from reciting Emily Dickinson poems out loud to myself in preparation for tomorrow's "poetry recitation." I need to make a list of reasons why my professor has been so disappointing this semester so I can write all of them down in her course review. Buh-arf.

I think I can say with some certainty, now, that my inability to focus this week has been related in some way to my TMJ problems. Here are some of the symptoms I've experienced: - Jaw pain - Jaw stiffness - Trouble opening jaw all the way - Jaw cracking when opening mouth - Aching pain even when not opening my mouth - Bad headaches - Nausea - Dizziness - Ear pressure - Ears itching - Ears feeling "full" (gross, I know) - Trouble sleeping at night I would say that a large part of my inability to focus has to do with these ailments. Because, you know, it's not like I haven't been trying to get my work done. It's just really, really difficult right now. Fortunately I went to the health center and doctor today. I was a little bit worried because I was seeing a nurse practitioner who has historically made light of many students' ailments. But she was actually fairly helpful and prescribed me some scary muscle relaxers that I'm only supposed to take at night because they will make me very, very sleepy. Kind of like my allergy medicine, I guess. Anyway, the point of this is that I feel awful like 95% of the time, I'm struggling to get my homework done, and I'm not doing anything superfluous right now. That means I'm just spending my time trying to feel better and trying to get my work done so I can fucking graduate in less than three weeks (!!!).

Is "inability to focus" a symptom of TMJ issues?  Because I think I have both and I am wondering if they go together.

Bah.  I think it's time for some Casino Royale annotated-bibliography-writing action.

Things I Will Be Glad to Never Ever Have to Do Again:
1. Annotated bibliographies.
2. Live with T--boy is super-messy and super-spacey.
3. Do bullshit assignments for Prof. B's class

Presumably there will be more to come as I get more and more stressed out in the next few weeks.

ENG 332
[X] Annotated bibliography (due May 6)
[X] Paper progress report (due May 11)
[X] Readings for May 12
[] Final paper (due May 20 by noon)
--- Progress: 0/13-15 pages

ENG 228
[X] Peer editing session (May 3 at 8:15pm)
[X] Poetry recitation
[X] Final paper (due May 14)

PHI 256
[X] Readings for Week 13
[X] Review readings for weeks 12 and 13
[X] Final paper (due May 18 by 5)

That's not terribly much.  I think I can do it!  Hurrah!

I'm so tired and so hungry. ARRRGH. My head hurts despite all the coffee I guzzled earlier, and I just kind of want to go back to bed until May 24th. Blerg. I may not be able to go to DIII nationals after all. Blah. This is silly. And I'm starting to get stressed out about all the homework I have for the end of the semester. Wooops. Also, the end of The Mill on the Floss is super-depressing. :( BUT all of this is outweighed by the awesomeness of going to Iowa City last night. What an epic evening!

5-6: Phi Beta Kappa dinner (barf?) 6-7: Research for 228 paper 7-8: Quintet rehearsal (?) 8-bedtime: WRITE 228 PAPER The end! EDIT: OMG that dinner was so full of awkward. Holy crap. I hate snooty academic things. Also I really don't want to go to quintet rehearsal. I am tired of it and I don't really even want to play in our concert. :( EDIT 2 (6:40pm): Oh god. I just chugged a giant glass of chocolate soy milk immediately after eating string cheese and wheat thins. So delicious, but so eaten-too-quickly. Urgh. Now I REALLY REALLY don't want to go to rehearsal. I mean, really. Why should I, other than that I committed to this at the beginning of the semester? People quit things all the time. Like jobs. And clubs and stuff. Although I really can't back out. I wish I could, though, because our flute player is nearly always out of tune and only has like two dynamic levels: "piercingly loud" and "slightly less obnoxious than piercingly loud." It is going to be kind of embarrassing to play at our upcoming concert. Oh well. At least DIII nationals will probably save me from the humiliation of performing at Senior Showcase. Also, thanks to all the frisbee I have been playing lately, my calf muscles have gotten rather large. It's kind of weird to accidentally touch one (I know it sounds weird, but whatever) and think, "OH GOD WHAT IS THAT MUTANT THING" and then realize it is my very own calf. EDIT 3 (6:51pm): LIST OF THINGS I DO NOT WANT RIGHT NOW: 1. To play my clarinet. 2. Gas. 3. Homework. EDIT 4 (6:52pm): Have I mentioned that I've been having dreams in Spanish a lot lately? It's weird and disorienting, but pretty cool nonetheless. Anyway. I guess I'll go trudge off to the music building now. EDIT 5 (8:25pm): Ugh. I am so unenthusiastic about the following things: 1. Quintet - barf. 2. This paper. Ugh. Things I miss (in no particular order): 1. Barcelona. 2. Kae Dog 3. My brother 4. John 5. Santa Fe - particularly green chile smothered all over everything. Mmmm. SIGH. EDIT 6 (9:15pm): This is becoming a live-blog of my day. Or a weirdly disjointed SOC. ANYWAY. So I am taking a break from Philosophy readings (gasp!  I know!  When was the last time I actually did my philosophy reading?) because they are kind of boring/confusing.  Tomorrow's lecture should clear things up a bit.

Anyway, I had a point to make . . . I forget what it was.  OH.  Right.  

I'm listening to Relient K (Two Lefts...) right now, and it's making me feel like I should be outside running on some insanely humid day.  That plus playing lots of frisbee lately has made me feel like I really need to commit to exercising once Institute/TFA starts, because otherwise I will just feel and look like a slob, and no one wants that.  I am a lot more content with life when I make time to work out, so I need to remember that when things start to get super-busy and I don't have frisbee practice to force me out of my serious slothdom.

That's it.  That's all I wanted to write about.  Nothing good here, sorry.  Just lots of thoughts about the future, frisbee (it's v. likely that we'll go to DIII nationals!), and some philosophy.  Wooo.

So far today, during my 2-hour break between classes, all I have accomplished is:

- Making coffee
- Heating up some lunch
- Converting songs from .ogg and .wma (I know, I know) files to .mp3 so that I can actually listen to them in iTunes.  This is the first inconvenience related to Logan Jr., but it's really not that bad.  I mean, this free software actually converts them quite quickly and at a high quality.  SO THERE.

I figure that all three of these things (particularly the music organizing thing) will help me sustain the extended periods of time I'll be spending writing papers and whatnot in the coming weeks, so it's not like I'm wasting my time.  Otherwise I'd be procrastinating for the next two weeks on music-file-conversion.  So.  Actually I'm being quite productive.

Anyway.  Time to convert a few more albums before Victorians.

This is my first-ever update from LOGAN JR.  He arrived today, 3 days early.  Thank god my Victorians seminar was cancelled today so that I could be at home to receive him into my arms (Apple requires a signature upon delivery; can't imagine why).  

Ahh, the smooth and functioning keys of this new addition to my family of technological devices!  Ahh, the beautiful glass screen!  And the lightness!  Oh, how he sits on my lap with such grace and elegance.  

Despite all of this, I find myself feeling slightly guilty.  Logan Sr. is still on my desk, doing all the things I usually ask of him--playing music, opening up Hyperbole and a Half so I can read that instead of my philosophy homework, etc.  Despite my recent frustrations with his inability to type things, his DVD drive's penchant for opening for no apparent reason, and his inability to open important files sometimes, I do have a soft spot in my heart for him.  He was my first computer, after all.  He went to Santa Fe and Europe with me, for crying out loud.  Logan Jr. has a lot to live up to.

Now the question becomes: what do I do with Logan Sr. while I use Logan Jr. for the remainder of the year??  I mean, naturally I'm going to write all of my final papers on this bad boy.  But Logan Sr. will just look so sad, all shut down forever in a corner or something.  Oh, what to do.  I find myself getting a little bit teary, just contemplating never using Logan Sr. again.  Maybe I can find some use for him, just to keep him around.  Just to show him I love him, no matter how technologically ancient he may be at this point.

OH SOB.






I do love this new computer, though.  I cannot get over how easy it is to type on this keyboard!  It's lovely and will undoubtedly make the paper-writing process that much more simple for me in the next few weeks.




But still.  I feel a little guilty.

Today I am reminiscing about the end of my semester in Barcelona, since it's been about a year.  It's actually really scary how quickly the time has passed.  I suppose that is the nature of time these days.  Or something.

Anyway, a year ago I was approaching the easiest finals week I've ever experienced and preparing to go to England.  A couple days ago, it was El dia de Sant Jordi (St. George's Day) and I got really nostalgic about Barcelona.  I miss it a lot, sometimes.  I miss the tiny cafe con leches, the chocolate croissants, and the structure of European cities.  I miss the public transit and the sunny weather (I only experienced one thunderstorm while in Barcelona).  Yet at the time, I was really excited to go home and do all kinds of things I couldn't do while in Europe--so I guess you win some, you lose some.

Now it's 2010 and my time at Grinnell is coming to an end.  I'm slightly more freaked about leaving Grinnell than I was about leaving Barcelona, but mostly because I still have a lot to do.  I only have two more full weekends in Grinnell, and that's only if I don't go home for David's graduation.  It's not so much that I wll miss weekend life at Grinnell.  Rather, I tend to count things off by weekends (at least this semester), and the fact that I only have two (at most) here is starting to scare me a lot!

I am excited about TFA, though.  Despite my neurotic social anxiety about it, I am very much looking forward to the challenge of working with students.  I am excited about working at my school next year and getting to be a part of a passionate community that's excited about something more important than self-indulgent weekend activities.  I'm excited to get away from a lot of the college mindset and culture, but there are a good number of people I will definitely miss.  

I don't really know why I'm writing this.  Perhaps it's a way to deal with my highly mixed feelings about college coming to an end.  Last semester and at the beginning of this semester, I was nothing but excited to get out of Grinnell for good.  Now that we're reaching the end, though, I'm definitely getting a little sadder about it.  A little.  

Oh well.  I think I'll go hang out with Maddie now.

(PS: Logan Jr. is in Memphis now!  Hurrah!)

It's raining.  Surprisingly, I am not sad about this.  It was nice to wake up to the patter of raindrops on my window.  Also the sounds of Lady Gaga emanating from the bathroom, where Thomas was taking a shower.

Perhaps my mood is about 1000000% times better than it otherwise would be because of the following things:

- Logan Jr. left Shanghai this morning on his way to me!
- I did all my reading AND finished my annotated bibliography/abstract a whole day early.  BAM.

Now I will celebrate/reward myself with some coffee and Hyperbole and a Half.

I was SO productive this morning (I didn't even take my habitual post-Philosophy nap, that's how motivated I was) that I thought I would have no problems finishing my annotated bibliography/abstract thing this evening. Then I discovered this. I've been reading it on and off all afternoon, giggling crazily to myself both in the privacy of my own home and while at work (oops). I feel like someone put Mia Thermopolis, Bridget Jones, and Natalie Dee in a blender to make one incredibly hilarious person. It is fantastic. Anyway. Today I am feeling much better than yesterday. MOOD SWINGS! Here are some reasons today is good: - I got my CREDIT CARD! It has a picture of beautiful mountains on it (I chose this design when applying for the card because I miss living near mountains). Commence Operation Buy A Mac! - I got some work done! I am proud of myself for starting this annotated bibliography trash so early (aka yesterday). It makes today-me feel good about myself. - We started learning about Wittgenstein today in philosophy, and he's the first dude whose ideas I actually like and understand. The latter is actually really important and so surprising that I want to keep reading his work to see if I can still understand it without the aid of my professor's incredibly detailed explanations. At any rate, I hope there is a paper prompt about him for the final paper. That is all. Time to go work some more on the stupid annotated bibliography . . .

Feeling v. down about everything.  Cannot think of anything about which I am excited, although Sectionals this weekend is like a faint light ahead in a very foggy present.  I don't know what's wrong with me, although I suspect that PMS is involved somehow.  

I wish school was over, but that I could play frisbee with the team whenever I wanted.  I wish I was living in Chicago, but in a place that was convenient for everyone involved.  I wish I wasn't so nervous about meeting all these new TFA people and having to make friends again after all the disastrous things that have happened with some of my friendships at Grinnell (and, of course, having to leave behind so many new and wonderful friendships found to fill to voids that others left).  I wish I was faster, leaner, and more aggressive when playing frisbee so that I would feel like I was contributing more to the team.

This week has been surreal and I just don't feel like doing ANYTHING right now.  I couldn't even muster the strength to cook tonight/any night this week, so tonight I bought a few frozen meals (in addition to other groceries) in anticipation of not having any prepared food for the rest of the week.  It's gross and lazy, but I am just feeling so icky and morose right now that I think eating frozen dinners out of their plastic containers fits well with my general feelings of extreme gloom.  Barf.

Well, it's been an interesting Tuesday. I'm a little upset with myself for leaving my application materials with an incompetent girl at the mailroom, who promised she would send them out UPS ground. Now I have almost no way of knowing whether she actually sent them out AND I didn't get a tracking number for the package. Hmmm. Sometimes I really lack foresight. Stupid stupid stupid. Regardless of my own stupidity, the level of incompetence at the mailroom is actually astonishing. No one knows what envelope to use for a UPS ground shipment, no one knows the password to be able to get into the computer that lets you create UPS labels, and no one knows when the supervisors who actually have this information will be back. It's really upsetting to me that I have to depend upon students who have no idea what they're doing. Unless you ask them to match your last name up with a parcel that's arrived for you, forget it. They have no clue. It's ridiculous and amazing to me that they aren't better trained to meet the needs of students who are likely sending out time-sensitive material to places like jobs, internships, families, etc. GARARARARARARARGH. Anyway. I should really be reading The Mill on the Floss right now. But I DO NOT WANT TO. It is so boring. Urgh. String cheese will probably help with this predicament.

Hmmm. A failed start to the day: I meant to go to my Philosophy class, but then when I woke up at 8:31 (the class starts at 8:30) I just decided--after much internal debate--to not go. Hmmm. Probably when I was a younger, more eager student I would have jumped out of bed and ran to class. Today . . . not so much. I am a little worried that this will negatively affect my participation grade, but then again part of me is all "meh." So, yes. I have three things I need to do today. Here they are: 1. Update the underclassmen report for SEPC. CHECK 2. Write the introductory 2-minute speech I will give tomorrow for our stupid debate. 3. Write a paper prospectus for my seminar. CHECK I think these goals are manageable. Now I just need to get started on them before I go to work. Oh, senior year.

Dislike group work v. much. Dislike overly-picky, constantly nervous and painfully awkward group member, with whom I've had to work with on TWO GROUP PROJECTS in the last TWO WEEKS. Ugh. Also dislike it when people don't answer emails. Like, seriously? Is it that difficult? GOD. EDIT (12:51pm): So so so so so so frustrated! By everything--the WRONG side of the debate that was held in my 228 class "winning," having to participate in another STUPID debate, having to go to seminar this afternoon and talk about literary criticism for TWO HOURS, stupid voicemails from advertising things with automated things that talk at weirdly varying speeds, the fact that Thomas puts baby powder in his shoes and then leaves BABY POWDER FOOTPRINTS in the house and expects no one to mind, the fact that I have to do all kinds of work for SEPC stuff and approximately half the people on it don't seem to give a shit about it, etc. RAAAAAAAAAAR!

Feeling all weird lately. Here are some feelings/thoughts I have been having in the past week or so that have been completely, utterly unexpected: 1. Am enjoying living in my house, despite the ants in the kitchen. 2. Am finding myself enjoying my housemates' company--which I've had more this week than pre-spring-break. 3. Today while biking home from the library, it suddenly hit me that, as ready as I am to get out of Grinnell and away from academia, I will miss springtime here, when the campus is all freshly-green and sunny. 4. I will miss frisbee an inordinate amount. 5. Due to some unfortunate papers that I wrote pre-spring-break, I am actually determined to do well in my classes (although this determination sometimes gets interrupted by strong bouts of not caring). 6. I am getting nervous about living in the city next year. This may all be due to the fact that I dropped my MAP and didn't have time to bask in its absence during midsems week. However, I am going to chalk it up to the sudden realization that we only have like, five weeks of class + one week of finals left. This is nuts. I've been pining away for graduation and now that it's imminent, I'm getting scared. What the hell? CONFUSED

Okay, I think I am going to stop writing in the style of Bridget Jones. At least, I will try. This means more 1st person pronouns and fewer weird British modifiers like "mad," etc. Today has been a good Sunday. I stayed awake immediately upon waking up (although the praise-worthiness of this is slightly undermined by the fact that I got up at 11:30), went to the store, and cleaned my room. While cleaning my room, I ordered transcripts for my Dominican application (paid ridiculous amount for stupid transcripts, though) and made a "Spring" playlist. Am v. satisfied, especially with the playlist as it is helping bolster my already caffeine-induced good mood! My windows are open and it's sunny and I plan on getting a lot of work done--right after I sweep my floor etc. EDIT (10:03pm): ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF THE DAY: 1. Cleaned room. It looks much more spacious than before. Hmmm. 2. Sprayed windows with bug keeper-outer. Hopefully no more ants in kitchen? 3. Finished In Memoriam, halfway through criticism now. 4. Copied and read part of Philosophy readings for Monday. 5. Applied for credit card (barf). 6. Returned all books that I checked out from library for thesis. Is like have really washed my hands of it now. 7. Grocery shopped. 8. Cooked sesame-tofu-broccoli thing with rice. Nom!

Holy crap, is suddenly and without warning a third of the way through April already and have not bought David a birthday present yet (is his 18th birthday on Wednesday). Maybe will buy him lunch then go shopping with him on Saturday when I'm home for that silly Spanish test thing. Anyway, this weekend has been lovely so far. Lots of frisbee, food, and friends. Friday after practice, had enormous leftovers potluck with Maddie and Hart that turned into an evening's affair with beer, ice cream, and everything. Today was more frisbee (coed scrimmage, not as fun as women's only but okay) and then dinner at La Cabana with Ethan. V.g. Am not sad at all about missing my last Drag Show, last Mary Be James, etc. because never really did care about those that much, anyway. Care way more about the people here than the silly events which am expected by some to take part in. Although I would assume that that expectation has disappeared over the course of nearly-4 years spent grumping around about Harris parties. Now am sitting in bed with a pile of books all around me, and for some mad reason I am reading In Memoriam by Alfred, Lord Tennyson. Mostly am reading it because I want to get ahead in mundane everyday schoolwork so can work extra hard on final three papers of undergrad. But the poetry and the elegiac style is growing on me. I guess. I still find I don't have that much to say about poetry, though, a problem that's plagued me since the beginning of college. Oh well. Am starting to feel happier here, suddenly, without really expecting it or trying. Will definitely miss many things about Grinnell when have graduated and moved into smog-plagued city, although more often than not I curse small-town Iowa for its isolation and lack of modern amenities (see: lack of SuperTarget). Oh well. Must read more Tennyson, or will be kicking self come Monday. Wahhooooo.

Hurrah! Random weird electrical things triggered fire alarms in building where had seminar this afternoon, resulting in getting out of class 10 minutes early (was v. boring in manner of high school class today). Also, frisbee practice canceled. This means can snuggle up under three blankets and bum around tonight. Oh, and finish philosophy readings and make post. Poop. Nap first. EDIT (12:09am): Oh fuck. Think just posted to discussion board for philosophy class asking question that amounted to, essentially, "WHAT IS THE POINT OF THIS!!!" Woops. Am in v. bad mood. Wish could just graduate already. Have enough fucking credits, anyway. Blagh.

Last night there was a terrific storm.  Highlights:

- Sitting in Intimate Dining with Ethan and Thomas to see the storm start.  Almost immediately, this transformer/generator/electric-y thing right outside our window started spewing black smoke and then the power went out.
- A hail-ball fight with Ethan and Thomas on the way home
- Taking a long, long nap in the dark (power was out at my house, too) and falling asleep to the sound of thunder rolling from pretty much every direction, without stop!
- Watching Bridget Jones' Diary with Thomas using Logan's remaining battery power
- Finding out from Ethan that Thomas and I slept through a tornado watch in which people on campus had to go into the basement of the JRC!!
- Going to bed really early for lack of anything better to do (is this what the pioneers did way back when?)
- Waking up this morning to see my fan spinning--electricity is back!

I'm glad nothing too terrible happened to me, although I did hear that trees fell on cars at one of the parks in town and that a tree like, crashed into this one family's house and broke a bunch of windows.  That is scary.

Anyway, I really don't want to go to my ENG 228 class.  Ever.  Again.  Oh well.  Looks like I've got to just suck it up, doesn't it?

Ew, I can't remember a time when I wanted to be in Grinnell less--with the possible exception of post-Thanksgiving-break-times first year.  The difference is that this time I had to drive myself back, meaning it was like some weird sort of self-inflicted torture to make the 5-hour drive back to this godforsaken town.

Spring break was awesome and nub times a bazilion, and although I don't mind having things to do in the form of homework/etc., I DO mind being in Grinnell, living in a house with roommates I don't much care for anymore and a school full of pretentious snobs.  Ugh.

Maybe my attitude about this whole finishing-senior-year thing will improve once I have obtained the requisite string cheese.

1. Triple interview punch during the 27-or-so hours between Wednesday at 1:30 and Thursday at 4:30.
2. Relatedly, I am nervous about meeting all of these people from the school where I'm interviewing.  I want to make a good impression, but am worried that I'll fall over or say something dumb in front of them.
3. Meeting TFA people.  I am afraid it will be like Barcelona redux, where I look forward to it and then get my hopes dashed because the people share absolutely zero things with me other than that we are humans and live on the earth.
4. My grades this semester.  So far I've slacked in every class because I was busy freaking out about/working on my thesis.  Now that I have the signatures needed to drop it for realz, I should have more time . . . but hopefully my grades aren't too shitty to salvage?
5. This paper I have to write for Wednesday.  Gah.  It's going to be bad.  I think.  I don't know.  We're supposed to find criticism and engage with it, but I just don't like the criticism I've found.  I think this is going to be one of those "rip off the bandaid quickly and get it over with" type of papers.

So, tonight I am going to work on #5.  Here goes.

<s>1. Sleep. A lot.</s>
<s>2. Revise essay for ENG 228.</s>
3. Begin research for ENG 332 short paper.
<s>4. WRITE LESSON PLAN FOR INTERVIEW AGGGHHH</s>

LOL I am such a bad student this semester. I have a 10-page paper due tomorrow afternoon and I HAVEN'T EVEN STARTED WRITING YET! I do have a bit of an outline going, though, so I guess that's something. I am now tucked away in my room, belly full of cheesy foods (not the greatest decision ever, but oh well) and getting ready to write this stupid paper. 6:14pm: PAPER WRITING COMMENCE. I am watching Casino Royale to facilitate this paper-writing experience, naturally. 6:46pm: Outline sort of done. Whatever. It's time that I started actually writing a paper. So far I have like 3 sentences. Yessss. 7:10pm: I am missing frisbee practice for this stupid paper. Gragh. I just finished page 1 of the paper, though! My goal is to write 8 solid pages. We shall see if that works out . . . 7:41pm: Watching Pokemon now. Just finished my second page! Wooooo. Feeling v. sleepy. Also my stomach hurtssss. 8:02pm: Hellll yes. Just finished page 3. 8:29pm: Ugh. Tummy feels funny. Tired. Need coffee. Have almost written four full pages. 9:33pm: Have coffee, am stuck in my writing. I hope my professor won't mind too much that I am using an internet encyclopedia to help achieve an understanding of this stupid philosopher man who interestingly turned out to be a Nazi. (And of course I'm going to cite the internet thing. No worries.) 9:50pm: Paper progress moving again. Am almost done with page 5. This is going rather more smoothly than anticipated. Maybe I will get to go home and take a nap after class tomorrow morning! YAY! 11:02pm: TIRED TIRED TIRED. Also, have hit a roadblock in this godforsaken paper. Augh. Paper is currently winning this night. 11:34pm: Upshot of all this paper-writing is that I think I now understand Frege's notion of sense really well. Bad thing: my finger (the one I jammed the other week at practice) hurts. Not good. 6.5 pages! Oh also I watched an episode of HIMYM and am now starting the Lion King. Obviously. 12:06am: OMG it's totally thundering out! Spring! Thunderstorms! Snow melting away! 11 days until I go to Portland! (that's weird, but cool!) I'm starting to get very very sleepy and am not really sure what it is that I'm writing anymore. Woooops. 12:42am: PAPER SLAIN. Well, perhaps not in terms of content/coherence, but DEFINITELY in terms of length. 8.3333333 pages, bitches.
